t.x: Native Korean number 1. Used for counting objects. Corresponds to Sino-Korean '일(一)'.
e: It's one.
Give me one, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of one is important.
Understanding the role of one in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: Native Korean number 2. Used for counting objects or people. Corresponds to Sino-Korean '이(二)'.
e: It's two.
Give me two, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of two is important.
Understanding the role of two in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

Understanding the role of one (sino-korean) in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: Sino-Korean number 100. Used for counting large numbers.
e: It's hundred.
Give me hundred, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of hundred is important.

t.x: Sino-Korean number 1,000. Often used for large numbers and prices.
e: It's thousand.
Give me thousand, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of thousand is important.
Understanding the role of thousand in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: Sino-Korean number 10,000. In Korean, the unit after thousand is ten thousand.
e: It's ten thousand.
Give me ten thousand, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of ten thousand is important.
Understanding the role of ten thousand in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: Sino-Korean number 0. Used in phone numbers and scores. Also called '공 (gong)'.
e: It's zero.
Give me zero, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of zero is important.
Understanding the role of zero in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: Half of a whole. Means 1/2. Also indicates '30 minutes' when telling time.
e: It's half.
Give me half, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of half is important.
Understanding the role of half in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: The very first in order. Short for 'first'.
e: It's first.
Give me first, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of first is important.
Understanding the role of first in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: Second in order. After the first.
e: It's second.
Give me second, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of second is important.
Understanding the role of second in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: The very end in order. Nothing more after.
e: It's last / final.
Give me last / final, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of last / final is important.
Understanding the role of last / final in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: A word used to ask about quantity or order.
e: It's how many / what (number).
Give me how many / what (number), please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of how many / what (number) is important.
Understanding the role of how many / what (number) in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.

t.x: The whole thing. Combined together. Without exception.
e: It's all / everyone / everything.
Give me all / everyone / everything, please.
Learning the pronunciation and usage of all / everyone / everything is important.
Understanding the role of all / everyone / everything in Korean number system makes quantity expressions natural.
